All right.
What we are working on today is we are still talking about
buffers.

This is from the handout from
Friday. And we will be continuing
throughout today and probably a

little bit on Wednesday on
acid-base titrations.

This is all in the acid-base
equilibrium unit. We were talking about buffers.
And so a buffering agent is

something where you can add acid
or base and the pH stays pretty

much neutral.
You usually add an acid and its conjugate base in the form of a
salt, or you add a base and its

conjugate acid in the form of a
salt. You have a dynamic equilibrium
going.

And when you add acid or base,
the buffering system acts as a source of protons or a sink of
protons to keep the pH pretty

much constant.
Let's work through a buffering problem and consider first the
initial buffering material.

And then what happens if you
add something to it, you stress the system,
add an acid or a base,

how the pH is affected by that.
In this case, we are adding one mole of an
acid and 0.5 moles of its

conjugate base in the form of a
salt, the form of a sodium salt

in this case.
And they are added together, and you add water and bring the
total volume up to one liter.

And you are given information
about the Ka of this particular

acid and asked to calculate the
pH under these conditions.

You can write this out,
as we've seen before, as an acid in water leading to
hydronium ions and the conjugate

base.
And you can set up a table to see how much you have in the
beginning and what you will have

at equilibrium.
We can set up this initial molarity, change in molarity and
equilibrium molarity.

But this time we have something
different. Now we have acid and the
conjugate base when we start.

In the problems we have looked
at, up until this point, these guys were both zero when
we started, but in a buffer

problem it is not zero.
You have some amount in there. And so we had one mole in one
liter, or molarity of 1.5 moles

in one liter or 0.5 molar.
Now, as it comes to equilibrium, we have the same
kind of change.

We have minus x over here,
plus x here, and plus x here.
And then, at equilibrium,

we would have 1 minus x,
x, and 0.5 plus x on the other side.
And, really,

a lot of the trick to doing
these buffer problems is remembering that you are
starting with something here and

here.
It really is not much more complicated than that
recognition.

And you would need to have
both. Otherwise, it is not going to
be a good buffer.

Now, if you have this
information set up, you know the Ka,
we can solve for x.

And x is what we want,
because we want pH. And pH is minus log of the
hydronium ion concentration.

We can set this up.
We are given the Ka. And this is going to be equal
to products over reactants,

the concentrations at
equilibrium. We have hydronium ion,
the conjugate base over the

conjugate acid.
And so we can fill this in, 0.500 plus x times x over 1
minus x.

Now, here you can do what we talked about last time.
And that is to first simplify

and see if we can get rid of
these x's here to make it easier to solve, or you can use the
quadratic equation.

But on the exam,
with the calculators you have, that is a little more
time-consuming,

so it is nice to see if you can
simplify. Basically we are saying,
how big is x if x is a small

enough number that it doesn't
really change this 1 or this 0.5.
Then you can sort of ignore it

and solve for x that way.
This is just written up again

that we had on the last side.
We are going to first try the approximation that x is small
compared to 1 and compared to

0.5 and solve that way,
and then go back and check and see whether that was valid or
not.

If we assume it is small,
we can rewrite that equation as 0.5 times x over 1.0,
which makes it easier to solve

and get an answer for x.
Which in this case is 3.54x10^-4 molar.
And now we can go back and take

this number, divide it by 0.5,
and see whether it is less than

5% of 0.5.
We are going to check the assumption and say is this
small?

And you don't need to do both.
If it is small compared to 0.5,

it will also be small compared
to 1.0, so you can just look at

the smaller number of the two.
Here it is less than 0.1%.

That is less than 5%,
so that assumption was okay. You can just go ahead with this
number.

Again, we have the 5% rule
there. This is the hydronium ion
concentration,

that was x.
Now we can find out the pH by taking minus the log of that
value, and that gives us an

answer of 3.45.
And we have two significant figures after the decimal point
because there were two

significant figures in the
volume. All right.
That is how you look at a

buffer problem.
And now we can say, was this a good buffer?
Let's consider what happens if

we add some strong acid,
HCl, 0.1 moles of it to this solution.
Again, in this case we are

keeping the total volume at one
liter. If you had made up your buffer
and added that 0.1 moles of the

strong acid to it,
what would be your pH? Is it about the same,
or did it dramatically change

the pH of the solution?
All right. Now you have to do some
subtractions to do this kind of

problem, and you have to
remember what we know about strong acids.
HCl is definitely a strong

acid.
And so we assume that when we add 0.1 moles of it that it is
going to react completely.

When we are adding the 0.1
moles, it will react with equal number of moles of the base.
The base is going to act as the

sink for protons,
it will react with the acid and you will form the conjugate,
the same equal number of moles

of a conjugate.
Here the base is reacting with the acid and trying to
neutralize the pH.

If we consider the HCOO minus
here, what we had originally,

we had 0.5 moles.
Now it has reacted with 0.1 moles of the HCl.
And so you only have 0.4 left.

And we have 0.4 in one liter.
We always need to convert to

molarity for these problems.
Now, in terms of the conjugate

acid over here,
we had one mole to begin with.

Now we have 0.1 moles more
because the strong acid reacted with the conjugate base to form
more of the conjugate acid.

Now our total is 1.1,
and that 1.1 is in that one liter.
And so we have a new molarity.

Now we can just do the same
thing we did before and solve for x, the hydronium ion
concentration,

which will give us the pH.
We can set up this expression again.
Now we have to put in our new

amounts, our 1.1 over here and
our 0.4 over here. We are still going to reach an
equilibrium.

x will be converted to plus x
over here. We have 1.1 minus x,
0.4 plus x.

We can use the same Ka value
that we had before to solve.

We can use the same
approximations. Set up the same equations.
Put in our new values over

here.
Do the same simplification. See if that works.
Solve for x.

The value for x now is
4.87x10^-4. And that is still okay.
It's only 0.12% of the smaller

number, the 0.4 number.
That is less than 5% so it is

fine.
And we can solve then for pH.

And now we get a pH of 3.31,
two significant figures after

the decimal point.
We had before, initially in a solution that
didn't have the strong acid,

a pH of 3.45 with 0.1 moles of
strong acid added.

The pH has changed slightly to
3.31. That is a decent buffer.
It didn't change really

dramatically when you added some
strong acid. This is a way that you can
manipulate a buffer,

if you are trying to design a
buffer at an exact pH. Then you can calculate.
You look at what kind of

buffering agent you want to use
and figure out how much strong acid or base you might have to
add to it to sort of adjust the

pH to where you want it to be.
That is one way of doing a

buffer problem.
Now let's consider designing a buffer, and how we would think
about going about it if you are

in a biochem lab,
for example, and you need to buffer
something at this pH,

how could you set these things
up? Some of the things you would
think about are the ratio of the

acid to its conjugate,
so the conjugate acid base pair, what ratio they have.
The pKa of the acid.

What pH you want to be for your
particular condition.

All right.
Now we are going to drive an equation that is going to help
you in designing buffers and in

doing buffer problems.
Here comes a derivation. The derivation starts with a
generic equation for an acid

buffer problem.
We have an acid, HA, in water forming hydronium
ions and the conjugate base.

We also know Ka,
the generic expression for Ka, products over reactants.
Or, in the case of this acid in

water, we have hydronium ions
times the conjugate base over

the conjugate acid.
Now we can take this expression and rearrange it.
We can bring Ka to the other

side and hydronium ions to the
other side of the equation. And then we can take the log of
both sides of the equation and

multiply both sides by minus 1.
This is the equation that we would get as the result of those
manipulations.

What is minus log of the
hydronium ion concentration? What else is that equal to?
pH.
And what about minus log of Ka,

what is that equal to?
pKa. We can substitute those in.
pH is going to equal pKa minus

the log of the concentration of
the acid over the concentration

of its conjugate base.
Here there are equilibrium concentrations because it came
from that equilibrium

expression.
Now, this is not that useful an expression to us.
We want to see whether we can

make it more useful.
And what would make it more useful is if we consider the
initial concentrations of the

acid and its conjugate base
rather than the equilibrium concentrations.
This will make it a more useful

expression.
At least Henderson and Hasselbalch thought that was a
pretty useful expression,

and I guess other people
thought it was as well since now it has the name
Henderson-Hasselbalch equation.

Usually things don't get named
unless they turn out to be fairly useful.
The simplification,

the approximation that is being
made here, is that the initial

concentrations are similar
enough to the equilibrium concentrations.
Let's consider when,

in fact, that would be true.
Here are the same expressions again.
What this is really saying is

that x is small,
something that we have been talking about for the last
couple of days.

x, in this case,
is the acid in equilibrium with its conjugate base.
x, the hydronium ion

concentration,
is small compared to the initial concentration of the
acid in the conjugate base.

The equilibrium concentrations
are more or less the same as the initial concentrations.
This is that approximation that

we have been using,
and we had been using that 5% rule, which we will continue to
use for the

Henderson-Hasselbalch.
This is assuming x is pretty small.
Another way of thinking about

this is that a weak acid
typically only loses a small fraction of its protons or
hydrogen ions.

It is weak.
By definition, a weak acid only loses a small
amount. A strong acid,
on the other hand,

pretty much ionizes completely.
And a weak base typically only accepts a small fraction of
protons or hydrogen ions.

Most of the time,
x is small; most of the time there isn't a huge change,
and most of the time you can

use that 5% rule.
Most of the time the initial concentrations are not all that
different from the equilibrium

concentrations.
This holds a lot of the time. And, again, the rule we will be
using is this 5% that the

concentration of hydronium ions
needs to be small, this over HA or A minus,
whichever of these is

the small number,
needs to be less than 5%. And if it is then you can use
this expression.

And that expression,
you will find out, turns out to make your lives a
lot easier in doing these

problems.
Now let's use this to design a buffer.
When would you use

Henderson-Hasselbalch?
We can consider it right here. Now, suppose you wanted a
buffer that is going to buffer

in the acidic range,
around 4.6. What we would do is go to a
table in the book and see which

acids have a pKa around 4.6.
And we could look down here.

That one is pretty close.
Let's see. Acetic acid,
that is not bad.

That is around that pH.
Let's pick that one. There are a couple other
options, but that was one that

would work.
Acidic acid is suitable. It has a pKa of 4.75.
And we want something around

the pH of 4.6.
And so most buffer solutions, something that is effective to
buffer at a particular pH if its

pKa is plus or minus one from
that pH, if the pKa is more than

one away from the desired pH
that is not going to be a particularly good buffer.
You want it within that range

of plus or minus one.
And that becomes important if you have, say,
an enzyme that you are studying

in a biochemistry lab.
If you are doing it at the wrong pH, the enzyme may not be
happy at all.

You might not get any results.
Let's use Henderson-Hasselbalch now to consider how much of each
thing we should add to make a

pretty good buffer.
Here is our equation again.

And we can consider these
original concentrations of the

acid and its conjugate base.
Now we can rearrange this to

solve for things that we know.
We know the pKa and we know the

pH that we want.
And so the pKa was 4.75. The pH that we want is 4.6.
We subtract that and get 0.15.

And then if we do inverse log
over here, we find that the

ratio of the acid to the
conjugate base that we should

add is a 1.4 ratio of those two.
What does this mean?

How much would you then add?
Well, you could, with this ratio,
add 1.4 molar of the acid and

one molar of the conjugate base.
But the exact amounts are not

as important as the ratio.
The ratio here is quite important because,
again, for it to be a good

buffer it needs to be able to go
both directions. If you add strong acid,
then that strong acid needs to

be able to react with the
conjugate base to keep the pH constant.
If you add strong base,

it needs to be able to react
with the conjugate acid, again, to keep the pH constant.
The ratio is important here.

The ratio is more important
than the exact amounts. But if you add too little then
you do not have enough of what's

called buffering capacity,
and you have less resistance to change.
The more that you have,

the more resistant to change
the buffer will be. So, if you have higher
concentrations,

the less likely it is that
there will be a problem that you will sort of swamp out your
system by adding too much acid

or base.
And if you use too low concentrations then you are not
going to make your 5% rule.

And the Henderson-Hasselbalch
equation will not be valid and you will not end up with the pH
that you think you are going to

because this will not tell you
the right answer under those conditions.
What would that be?

Well, you can go back and
calculate what is sort of the minimum concentration that one
would need to keep your 5% rule?

For a pH of 4.6,
that is equal to hydronium ion concentration of 2.5x10^-5.
And so if you put that up here

then either of these,
the smaller one of these, for this to be less than 5%,
you can go back and calculate.

And so you would need at least
5x10^-4 over here for the 5% rule to work.
If you had less than that,

then the equation wouldn't be
valid.

OK.
We are working our way through this list, and we will move into
today's handout.

Remember, there are only five
types of problems, and the trick is to figure out
which type of problem it is and

apply the right kind of
procedure to it. Again, the two easiest ones we
have left are the strong acid

and the strong base in water.
And then we are going to go

into acid-base titrations which,
in one problem of an acid-base

titration, you can do almost all
of these different types of

problems.
Titrations are really a summary of all the types of problems put
into one problem.

Acid-base titrations.
And I will say, before we get started,
that acid-base titration

problems are often the problems
in this half of the course that people struggle with,
although the year before last

there was an actually quite good
performance on acid-base titrations.
And so last year I told the

class that the year before had
been quite good, and I was curious to see how
they would do in comparison to

this pretty good year.
And they responded and did a really fantastic job.
So I am beginning to think that

this, in fact,
is not a hard unit necessarily. It is a little bit different,
I think, but you just have to

work the problems.
And there are problems on the problem set to work.
And then it starts to come

together.
I am really optimistic that this year's class can even
outperform last year's class.

I mean you did on Exam 2,
so I feel like this will be a little contest to see if people
can do better than last year.

Acid-base titrations,
you will see them again. If you take organic chemistry,
you will talk about pKa's all

the time.
Biochemistry, you are going to talk about
acids and bases and buffers and pKa's.
If any of you are going to

medical school,
oh boy, will it be back big time.
When I was a graduate student I TA'ed medical students,
and pretty much all we were

doing was acid-base titrations,
getting through it. If you learn it now,
you are just going to make

many, many years ahead be much
easier. All right.
Acid-base titrations,

what is this?
Well, you are basically titrating an acid with a base or
a base with an acid.

Often they are used to find out
an unknown concentration. If you know the concentration
of one thing you are adding,

you can find out the other.
Let's just look at some of these things.
Here you would have a strong

base on top, in this picture,
and a strong acid in this flask here.
And you are dripping amounts of

strong base into the strong
acid. And you can calculate out a
titration curve.

Here we have pH versus volume
of base added. At the very beginning,
we are very acidic pH.

We only have strong acid at
zero volume. And then, as you add base,
you eventually get to a point

called the equivalence point or
the stoichiometric point or sometimes called the end point.
And here are some of the

definitions of those.
Basically here the number of moles of acid is equal to the
number of moles of base that you

have added, so equivalence or
stoichiometric because they are equal amounts here.
And it is often called the end

point because experimentally,
when you get to that point, you are at the end of your
experiment.

And this one is really a
theoretical. This is experimental.
They should,

in fact, equal each other.
You can measure pH up here with the pH meter.
And when you are doing these

kinds of acid-base titrations,
you often see something like this.
You have some kind of dye which

indicates when you have reached
the endpoint. And so it will be clear,
clear, clear and then all of a

sudden you will start seeing
this change in color. And you want to measure the
endpoint when you just start to

see that change.
How many of you have actually done these titrations in a lab?
Almost everybody,

okay.
What happens often, at least when I did it,
you would be going along really

slowly, drip,
any change, drip, any change.
And finally you just get incredibly frustrated and you
add just a little bit more,

and all of a sudden it is
really, really bright color and you have gone too far.
But then you can sometimes back

calculate approximately where
the end point should be and go fast to that point and then go
kind of slowly.

And so it sometimes helps to be
able to do these sort of theoretical calculations to help
you figure out when you need to

drip slowly.
How many of you have had that same kind of experience of
really, really slow and then all

of a sudden bright colors?
How many people did it perfectly one time?
OK. We have just a handful of
people who did that perfectly.

All right.
Some people ask me, why don't we have a lab course
affiliated with our GIR courses?

A lot of times you have a lab

kind of thing.

It would be hard because you

But I tell people mostly you

Because I think most freshman

college courses,
pretty much this is what you do most of the semester.
So, you have already done it.

And you will learn how to do it
on paper. And so the next couple days,
this problem set,

you can declare that a lab
experience and feel like you have saved yourself an

actually being in a laboratory
doing the drip, drip, drip, drip experiment.
You are not missing out on too

much for this.
Later courses, I think the labs become
increasingly valuable to

understanding the material and
can be a lot of fun. And, of course,
research experience is

fantastic.
The UROP program here is spectacular.
All right. Acid-base titrations here.
Let's look at the shapes of the

other kind of curve.
We can do the reverse experiment and have strong acid
up here dripping into strong

base.
And so in the beginning you just have strong base,
so you are up here in the

curve.
You add some until you get to the stoichiometric or
equivalence point,

and then it is equal amounts of
acid and base. And then, as you keep adding,
your pH drops because then you

start having more strong acid in
here. These are the shapes of these
curves, and you should know how

to draw these and you should
know how to calculate various different points on those
curves.

Let's look at that.
Here we have a strong base,

NaOH, and it is being titrated
with a strong acid,

HCl.
And so we are going to calculate just a couple of
points on that curve.

Let's start by doing 5 ml's of
the acid that has been added to

25 milliliters of our strong
base.

And let's figure out what the
pH will be at 5. First, what we have to do is
calculate how much OH is

present.
And remember for strong acids, strong bases,
you say that the amount of NaOH

added is going to be equal to
the amount of OH formed.

The NaOH completely ionizes
into sodium plus and OH

minus.
We can calculate the number of moles.
We know the volume.

We know the concentration.
We had 25 ml's. We know this and can calculate
the numbers of moles.

Then we have to figure out how
much acid was added. We added 5 milliliters.
What does that correspond to in

terms of moles?
Again, it is a strong acid. We can say for the amount of
HCl that was added,

we have formed completely
hydronium ion. It is completely ionized.
It is a strong acid.

You have complete conversion to
the acidic form to hydronium

ion.
We had 5 ml's times the concentration of acid that was
given.

And now we know how many moles
of acid were added.

Now we are going to have a
reaction between the base and

the acid, so these will react.
And so if we had 6.25x10^-3

moles of hydroxide ion,
and we are going to subtract

the amount of acid that is
formed to find out how much OH

is left.
We just subtract those. There is a complete reaction,
one to one.

And so we just subtract the
amount of acid to get the numbers of moles.
Then we need to convert that to

molarity.
Here, we have the number of moles that we just calculated
divided by our new volume.

We added 5 ml's of acid and we
had 25 ml's to begin with, so now we have 30 total and we
can calculate the concentration.

And I will just mention that
this is one of the common mistakes that people make on
exams when you are hurrying,

and it is not to actually
figure out the total volume that you have at that moment.
Put maybe a little star by it

to remind yourself to do this
addition here, because if you have the wrong

coming out very strangely.
Once you have the concentration,
then it is easy to calculate

pOH.
Now, this is, again, the concentration of
hydroxide ions that we had.

If we take the minus log of
that, we get the pOH. And then
we need to change it to pH.

All of the problems you will do
are at room temperature,

so you can always use 14 for
your conversion, and you come out with a pH of
13.18.

Now we have our first spot on
the titration curve.

We had volume of acid.
We were adding 5 ml's to begin

with.
This is pH. And we are starting out here.
That's back a little.

At 5 ml's we are up at 13.18,
so we are at quite basic pH.

And remember that as you are
doing these problems, if you had ended here and
decided that was your pH,

think about the fact that you
have mostly strong base at that point.
You realize you need to do this

conversion to go to pH.
Now let's figure out about the equivalence point.
We need to know the volume to

get to the equivalence point.
How much acid do we need to add?
Well, initially we know how

much OH was present.
At the equivalence point, by the name equivalence or
stoichiometric,

you need equal amounts of the
acid. If this is how much we had in
moles, this is how much we are

going to need in moles of HCl.
We just need to find out what volume we need to add to get
those numbers of moles.

And so here are the moles.
This was the concentration of acid we were given.
And so that means we are going

to need 18.4 milliliters to
reach the stoichiometric or equivalence point.
And what will be the pH at that
equivalence point?

Strong acid mixed with a strong
base. 7.
It will be neutral.

Somewhere around here,
we are going to have a pH of 7 when we get to 18.4 milliliters
of acid added.

Strong acid,
strong base, the equivalence point pH will
always be 7.

If you are starting to talk
about a weak acid or a weak base, it will not be 7,
but for strong acid,

strong base it will always be
7, will always be neutral.

What about if we add 1 ml
extra? We have reached the
stoichiometric or equivalence

point, and now we are going to
add an extra mL of acid, what is going to happen?
You can do this a couple of

different ways.
I think this is probably the simplest, is just to say how
many extra moles is that?

If concentration was 0.34,
we are adding 1 mL extra, so we are going to add
3.4x10^-4 moles of acid extra.

And then we just need to find
out the concentration of that. The only trick here again is to
remember that you have to add up

all of the correct volume.
You had 25 to begin with. You have added 18.4 milliliters
to get to the equivalence point

and you have added 1 mL beyond
the equivalence point, so you have this new volume.
And we have this number of

moles of acid.
Then you can calculate the

concentration from that and then
take minus log of that number to

get the pH.
And so we can put that down here.
When we go sort of 1 milliliter

beyond, now we are down at a pH
around 2.116.

We started at very basic pH.
We added 18.4 milliliters to

get to pH 7, to the equivalence
point. And then, if we keep adding
acid, the pH drops pretty

dramatically.
And now you are quite acidic. That is how you would calculate
points on a curve for a strong

acid, strong base titration.
And so we will have two kinds of curve shapes here.
This one that we just talked

about.
And then, of course, if you are going to the other
direction, you will start at a

low pH when you have acid,
reach the stoichiometry point at pH 7 and then keep going.
As you add more base,

it will get more basic.
Now let's talk about when the acid is weak or strong.
The only kinds of problems

here, you either have strong
with strong or you have a weak acid with a strong base.
Or strong with strong.

Then we also could have a weak
base and a strong acid, but you never are going to have
two weak things titrating each

other.
